comment.author: SugeKnight_StandOver
comment.body:
EGR - Days like today convince me that my original trading strategy of selling for pips and buying dips is the correct way. "Lost" 10k today on paper (could have made 10k if sold on open and then bought back at my original buy in at close).
Let's hope im wrong and going long pays off better, with a bit of patience.
Currently sitting on pretty much break even +0.75%
My original strategy's downfall is that you can sell for pips and then suddenly the stock rockets to xxxx% and you missed out on the "real" tendies. It only works if you are content with the strategy and smaller gains, and not be bothered if the stock rockets (otherwise you spend your days saying "I'm so dumb , why did I sell , etc etc)" and it fucks with your brain. Other times it causes you to buy back in at ATH and then lose your original gains and more.
Let's wait and see how this goes. Have confidence with the stock so that helps

comment.body:
Not really sure what to think of this honestly. I was holding NYR and I sold at 20% profit (4k profit seemed pretty awesome at the time). Not 2 weeks later, it went to a ATH and I missed out on potentially making 20k over the 4k.
So anyways couple of weeks later, was holding Vr1 and was in the profit over 3k, but thought not making the same mistake. That stock started falling like no tomorrow and i had to sell for a loss of 3k (lucky I did or else I woulda copped it massive since it has fallen so much since then).
Moral of the story: I've got no fucking idea.

comment.author: Dark_Raiden_
comment.body: It depends. Most stocks recover from those pullbacks when the broader market sinks or when they have profit taking, and then can go beyond that 30% if the fundamentals are there, though it can take a while. Most of the time after something like a 30% gain profits will start receding, it just depends on your time frame what you wanna do. I know for a fact if I sell at 30% profit the stock will rocket more, but if I don't sell it will crash so idek what to do.

comment.author: SugeKnight_StandOver
comment.body:
EGR - Days like today convince me that my original trading strategy of selling for pips and buying dips is the correct way. "Lost" 10k today on paper (could have made 10k if sold on open and then bought back at my original buy in at close).
Let's hope im wrong and going long pays off better, with a bit of patience.
Currently sitting on pretty much break even +0.75%
My original strategy's downfall is that you can sell for pips and then suddenly the stock rockets to xxxx% and you missed out on the "real" tendies. It only works if you are content with the strategy and smaller gains, and not be bothered if the stock rockets (otherwise you spend your days saying "I'm so dumb , why did I sell , etc etc)" and it fucks with your brain. Other times it causes you to buy back in at ATH and then lose your original gains and more.
Let's wait and see how this goes. Have confidence with the stock so that helps

comment.author: maybethough
comment.body:
Asia might keep sliding. I checked for a nice bounce this morning when everything was bright green but it didn't do shit. It used to push harder with blood on the streets than it did this morning.
Tech isn't the play right now. Follow the trends (for ETFs: FOOD, and if you want to diversify fairly safely then QFN and BNKS until people get an appetite for technology again. If you want Asia style risk and growth then you have to go to the US markets and get msos or one of the mining ones, because hack/acdc/whatever are all dogshit in this climate)
Edit: the stocks that ASIA holds are extremely good, especially TSM - like as good as a growth ETF could hope for - but they're a victim of their own success and too much money poured in

comment.author: Impressive-Pass-8698
comment.body:
Got a few quick questions baout BBOZ/BBUS if anyone has used them before and can help a brother out. what's the liquidity like? say it goes up %4, is kit hard to sell at the end of day?
And is it even worth doing in small amounts, like is T+2 ing it a bad idea coz of the brokering costs?

comment.author: Goody55
comment.body:
Bboz is always liquid, the fund makes buy in/out always available. Youll see how it works in the buy/sell quotes, theres 90k shares available to sell and buy at each pip
EDIT: Cant comment on T+2 plays but there was a very good post about 3 weeks ago on this sub which talked about how this fund deteriorates over time making it a bad long term play

comment.author: timbuckley66
